statement.p: There is a version of Pythagoras that applies here even though \theta\neq\degree{90}, called the law of cosines: a^2 + b^2 - c^2 = 2ab\cos\theta, where a is the length of \uvec{u}, b is the length of \uvec{v}, and c is the length of the hypotenuse across from \theta. (If \theta were \degree{90}, the right-hand side of this equality would be zero and this law would collapse to the same equality as Pythagoras.)

Use the formulas from to rewrite the left-hand side of the law of cosines in terms of the components of \uvec{u} = (u_1,u_2) and \uvec{v} = (v_1,v_2), then simplify until you get 2\times(\text{simple formula}).

postlude.p: Using the new expression 2\times(\text{simple formula}) from as the left-hand side in the law of cosines, and dividing both sides by 2 a b, we get \cos\theta = \frac{(\text{simple formula})}{\unorm{u}\unorm{v}} . (Remember that a and b are the lengths of \uvec{u} and \uvec{v}, respectively.)

The simple formula part of this angle formula turns out to be an important one it is called the Euclidean inner product Euclideaninner product inner productEuclidean or standard inner product standardinner product inner productEuclidean (or just simply the dot productdot product) of \uvec{u} and \uvec{v}, and written \udotprod{u}{v}.
